intro: Acacia tenuifolia, commonly known as the narrow-leaf acacia, is a shrub native to southern Africa. It is characterized by its slender, feathery leaves that are often covered in a fine layer of white or grey hairs. The plant produces yellow, globular flowerheads that appear in late winter or early spring. It is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, making it drought-tolerant and suitable for xeriscaping. Acacia tenuifolia is also valued for its ornamental appeal and is sometimes used in traditional medicine.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia tenuifolia is primarily native to the arid and semi-arid regions of Australia. The plant plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for native wildlife.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acacia tenuifolia was mainly introduced to areas with arid or semi-arid climates, where it thrives in well-drained soils. It is commonly found in regions of Australia, particularly in the Northern Territory and Western Australia.
